title: @Riot, before you make pass on AP items, I think it is important to understand why they are so bad
body:
Riot said they are preparing a pass over AP items, because they are so underwhelming, and that they welcome suggestions, but I think that there is much more important issue to discuss.

Please compare how many different stats are there available to put on item for AP champions vs AD champions:

AD - > AS, AD, LS, Crit, Lethality, %Pen, CDR
AP - > AP, CDR

I know what boards want to say now:
'But there is also mana and penetration to put on AP items, too!' - 

No, there isn't. See, armor is much more abundand than MR (due to oversaturation in armor penetration), so that more Magic penetration items can't really be added - indeed, when MR aura was removed, even 3 items we have now were too much and led to giving more free MR to all ranged champions. Adding more impactful magic pen item would make mages unstopable, and that's not the goal.

Same applies to mana - most AP champions get a single mana item, some of them can get two. The system already inludes all mana items we could ever want - indeed, with a little good will even ROA and Archangels could (and should) be merged into single item, they are vrtually identical (scaling over time + mana + AP + hp/shield).

The TL;DR here is that item system __in it's very core__ doesn't offer enough for AP champions - not only AP items are in a state that is far from satisfactory, it's hard to even imagine an item that would change that - we don't need 13th AP/CDR item, CDR is capped and AP stacking doesn't scale that well.

So, my proposals focus on introducing new options for AP champions

* AP upgrade for Kircheis Shard
   - there are many AP champions who would enjoy AP/AS item, but their kit doesn't support DPS playstyle enough to invest in pure DPS item like Tooth. Energized attack would give them a middle ground between burst and dps style. Potential users: {{champion:268}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:119}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:38}} {{champion:10}} {{champion:85}} {{champion:96}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:61}} {{champion:17}} {{champion:4}} 

* Empowered recall item
  - mages are the only class that needs to recall lategame, that's a fact (a bit streched, but still). While this is OK as a weakness, allowing them to build to partially mittigate it would be a cool option. Potential users: every mana reliant mage.

* tower-damage as a statistic
  - right now 50% AP is converted into tower damage. Making that number item dependant (i.e. it would start at 40%, but could go up to 70% if build for) would be interesting and would introduce new element that AP item system lacks.

* new iteration of mejai's
  - Mejai's is cool in that it's snowball passive is something that AP system has but AD system doesn't (anymore). It has, however, absurd abuse cases on super-safe champions like Janna, Soraka and Lux - what leads to it being nerfed until it's only viable on those, and barely at that. I think that it could be made into cool, viable item if those cases were gated I.e. stacks could be only granted if you were close to dying enemy (partial gating from super-safe champions) and stacks increase your damage (as oposed to AP, completely gating from Janna and Soraka).

I wonder if there's room to remove "the" mana item from a mages build. 

Like, what if instead of having to start {{item:3165}} {{item:3027}} {{item:3070}} ({{item:3174}} in years past) to get a large pool of mana/mana regen, then moving on to your core stuff, most of the AP items gave a little bit of mana but not a ton. 

Right now the prevailing strategy is "buy your way out of your mana problems, then never think about them again." Shouldn't choosing to sacrifice a mana item give you *some* advantage over the person who went a mana item first? If there were core mana items, but then more items gave a little bit of mana, it would encourage builds that are stronger if you can manage your mana better.

---------

Everyone knows the breakdown, but it's still worth bringing up when finding out what works for AD, and hopefully what could change for AP.

{{item:3134}} builds into {{item:3147}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3814}} = 1 interactive passive, 2 active items
{{item:3136}} builds into {{item:3151}} = Deal DoT passive. More DoT if target is CCed 

**Take away lesson:** More options is good. Interactive passives or actives also make for more interesting items. "Interactive" isn't playing the same way you always would and getting different results (which is what happens with Liandries right now). Being forced into buying another item to get the most of it {{item:3116}} isn't exactly interactive either.

{{item:3155}} feels smart to buy, has a passive that saves your life. 
{{item:3191}} feels like a chore to buy, with no visual indication when it saves your life.

**Take away lesson:** Similar to auras, some sort of big, obvious visual saying "Hey, I'm doing something!" can go a long way in making an item feel better.

{{item:3031}} amplifies the damage that ADCs get from other crit items, gives AD and Crit Chance, and is an early core item
{{item:3089}} amplifies the damage APCs get from other items, gives only AP, and is almost never built because of its cost

**Take away lesson:** One trick pony items have to be pretty broken to win out over their generalist brethren. Even adding one other stat can make a difference (being a bit cheaper helps too)

{{item:3035}} builds into {{item:3036}} {{item:3033}} , letting you chose which upgrade works best in that game
{{item:3135}} builds into nothing

**Take away lesson:** "Condition X exists, I should build Y" is less interesting than "Condition X exists, and Condition Y exists, I should consider Option Z". 

-----------

I'm sure there are more (I feel like the Zeal upgrades have something to share), but this is a starting point for what could change.

They were told all of this last year when they did the mage update. The Developers didn't listen to anyone one bit and I actually think they nerfed them even more with the tank update. Most people are under the impression that ADC and Tanks are too strong. I don't think they are as bad as people think. The problem is Riot didn't introduce or actually work on AP itemization and, if I remember from the tank update, they raised MR and health on tank items. When they did both the Tank and ADC updates, Riot included complete overhauls of items, mechanics, and introduced new items that actually matter. What did the team do to AP itemization that made it better? Offer more CDR on items? That really helped, didn't it? 

Champions that utilize auto attacks or AP bruisers are still suffering and not that great. They have hardly anything in their arsenal to deal with tank champions now and the amount of damage and survivability ADC have now. I mean really look at ADC and Tank itemization and see how different their itemization is. Tanks and ADC all have items with tons more useful actives, mechanics that save them from death so they can stay alive long enough to kill enemies, and decisions to pick the right item for specific uses. AP champions have a belt that lunges they forward and shoots out missiles. AP champions have a freeze gun that shoots out ice spikes. GREAT JOB THERE.

What Riot needs to do is:

1) GIve magic pen more options like ADC have. I mean if AP champions had more decision making in their items it would make them more interesting to play and feel great.
2) More unique actives that aren't a belt shooting out rockets and a freeze gun shooting out icicles. I also think Liandrys Torment should get an actual active that does more damage to health stacking champions.
3) Lower the cost of Rabbadons, increase the amount of AP on it, or add some new mechanic to it. Seriously. Rabbadons costs too much for the price of not really providing anything.
4) More MR/Armor items that have AP attached to it. Look at ADC who have more than 3 items with armor/MR attached to it with attack damage. I mean they even get a dumb cleanse item that protects them from CC. What do mages get? A belt that lunges them forward and shoots missiles out. An ice gun that shoots icicles out. Enough said.
5) Bruiser AP champions need more options and a ton of work.

Honestly Utility mages feel pigeonholed. They have poor AP ratios to their base damages, so they're essentially forced into buying {{item:3135}} {{item:3020}} {{item:3151}}, and the three item slots left often have items with the same passive competing.

{{item:3027}} wants build for the extra staying power it gives
{{item:3001}}  wants built for the bonus damage it provides bypassing AP
{{item:3030}} wants built for the massive utility spell it grants

But all three have the same passive, and Frost Bolt is the only utility item available for casters without going into meme territory ({{item:3092}} {{item:3060}} {{item:3056}} {{item:3091}} {{item:3512}} ). They're left with then wasting money on non-optimal AP on any combination of {{item:3116}} {{item:3285}} {{item:3157}}  

It gets even worse for characters like Anivia that build {{item:3040}}, limiting their item diversity game-to-game to all of a single item slot.

There needs to be more utility options for mages that can't afford building 600 AP just to do more than the base damage of their spells.

If stacks increased your damage output instead of your AP, then Mejai's Soulstealer would just become an item for everyone. Physical assassins, divers, juggernauts and marksmen would all buy an item like this.

Now, if you are specifically intending for Mejai's Soulstealer to increase magic damage by a percentage, that would be an issue. AP ratios are how Riot is able to specifically tune each mage's damage from items based on how much base damage they are able to deal. A % damage amp is ridiculous, that's one of the reasons it had to be removed from Abyssal Scepter and given to a tank who has to stand near the mage instead of just giving it to all mages themselves.

An empowered recall item for mages is very interesting (though I would debate whether mages are the only class that is forced to recall, I would argue that Sighstone also demands supports return to base during the late game quite often). 

Perhaps a different idea would be like a mage's version of Warmog's Armor. An item that gives you % mana regeneration only out of combat that is quite expensive and offers little offense. Maybe something like -
